ANNUAL BUDGET STATEMENT


    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [8th March, 1971], "That Parliament approves the financial policy of the Government for the financial year 1st April, 1971 to 31st March, 1972.". [Minister for Finance].

    Question again proposed.

2.32 p.m.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan (Crawford)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, first of all, I wish to thank the new Minister for Finance because in his first budget presented to this House, there is no increase in the rates of taxation nor are there any new taxes to be imposed. However, this does not mean that I fully endorse the measures implemented in the last financial year and those to

Column: 675

be implemented in the new financial year. On the contrary, I would like to take this opportunity to express my views on certain matters which are not altogether on all fours with those of the Government.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, as a small nation, Singapore is subject to the influence of many extraneous factors which are beyond our control. These factors often affect the decisions that we have to make. The political and economic developments in our neighbouring countries will always have a certain bearing and reaction in our country. Therefore, whatever we decide and do, we must not overlook all these extraneous factors. To do otherwise would be most unwise on our part.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister for Finance has resorted to a mass of statistics to show how satisfactory our economic growth has been over recent years. I am not an economist, nor am I prepared to degrade myself into becoming a theorist and, in an air-conditioned room, talk about the poverty outside. My view is that all this talk of economic growth and progress will be entirely meaningless if they do not bring real benefits and a better life for the general public and ensure a more equitable distribution of wealth. If our progress and economic growth bring benefits only to a small group of people and make the few who are rich richer, that will generate social discontent and lead to a latent crisis.

    The Minister for Finance says that in recent years the prices of commodities in our country have been quite stable and that there has been no appreciable increase in the cost of living. Sir, I cannot agree with him on this. As a matter of fact, at the very moment when this budget is being presented to this House, there are moves to standardise or adjust commodity prices for various reasons. These so-called price standardisation and adjustments are nothing more than pronounced price increases. Unless we adopt the attitude of an ostrich, I say that the so-called stabilised prices are not borne out by facts. I hope

Column: 676

the Government will look into this matter and not avoid it and shirk its responsibility, because this matter concerns the livelihood of the people in the street. They cannot remain indifferent. The present trend in price increases should be checked and proper attention should be given to it by the Government.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the budget for this year is more or less similar to that of last year and the following points have been stressed. First, the creation of a favourable climate to attract foreign investments. Secondly, the establishment of a sound infrastructure for an industrialised state. Thirdly, the training of much needed personnel, particularly middle level technical and managerial personnel for our industrialisation. Fourthly, the promotion of tourism as well as urban renewal and other development plans. On the face of it, there is nothing wrong with all these measures. For example, the creation of a favourable investment climate is conducive to our economic development and security. The more international consortiums we can attract into our country, the greater will be our ability to create employment opportunities, develop higher technology and promote economic growth. We will be able to develop our potential to attract even more investors so as to make Singapore the investors' paradise. They come here not for sentimental reasons. Furthermore, in their own interest, they will ensure that we are safe and continue to maintain this stability so as to ensure that their investments are safe and have good prospects. I would, however, remind the Government not to overlook the support and assistance to be given to local capital. I feel there is a great deal of capital which can be tapped locally. Many locally financed industries have, in fact, been very successful in recent years. I would like to give one example. The Far East Shipbuilding Industries in Jurong is a business enterprise financed solely by local capital, which has recently entered into an agreement with an American company for technical co-operation.

Column: 677

This shipyard has been able to win multi-million dollar contracts for shipbuilding projects. The Government has the duty to assist this kind of local entrepreneurs with ability and foresight in the industrial field, because the moment other countries are able to offer foreign investors better terms, they will not remain in Singapore for sentimental reasons. They do not owe us a living. Therefore, in the circumstances, it will be short-sighted to ignore the exploitation and development of the potential of local capital.

    In my view, the assistance which must be given to local capital and the attraction of foreign capital into Singapore are complementary to each other. There is nothing inconsistent about that. I would like to give yet another example. Jurong Shipyard Limited, a joint venture between Japanese and local capital, and its sister company, Jurong Shipbuilders Limited - now under construction - are dependent upon extensive local supporting industries to be successful. Recently new enterprises have been formed to provide con sultative and construction services to the setting up of new industries, which also need extensive supporting industries. So we should utilise every opportunity to utilise local capital to develop such supporting industries. In this way we will be able to increase employment opportunities and upgrade our technological skill level. I would like to express the hope that the Government's planning and efforts to train industrial, technical, managerial and other personnel will meet with the success that they deserve in order to fulfil the needs of our industries.

    The Minister for Finance has also made reference to tourism. It is a sad thing to see that the Tourist Promotion Board, which has been charged with the duty of promoting tourism, has seen fit to send overseas as a publicity move some temple mediums who actually represent a backward and superstitious era. Recently the Tourist Promotion Board has even thought of erecting

Column: 678

some kind of wax museum to commemorate the historical events of the shameful deeds and atrocities of the Japanese militarists in Singapore. If members of the Tourist Promotion Board are not capable of better ideas than this or of bringing about a better publicity campaign, they will have to face the condemnation of the people and do a lot of explanation. I hope the Government will unreservedly turn down all these kinds of publicity stunts and proposals which are an insult to the dignity of our people. Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not deny that the promotion of tourism is important to our economic growth. But I think we have many other better ways of doing it, such as the establishment of bird parks and large zoos, and the publicising of our multi-cultural and multi-religious features, and many other aspects of local life which will help make tourism a success. We have indeed a lot to learn from more advanced countries like Japan and Taiwan.

    I would like to turn now to the Minister's remarks on urban renewal. My constituency is the first to be affected by urban renewal. In this respect, the people in my constituency have made considerable sacrifices for national construction. But does the Palembang Housing Estate - a new housing estate in my constituency - meet the objectives behind the urban renewal scheme? If a survey is made amongst the flat dwellers and the traders there, they will say that this housing estate is far from satisfactory. They complain of inconvenience in traffic and poor designs of the flats, as a result of which tourists are not attracted there. Because of this, business is very poor in this area. Mind you, Sir, these businessmen have to pay many times the rent that they used to pay before urban renewal. The people living there find it rather inconvenient and, particularly in times of emergency, even police vehicles and ambulances find it difficult to go in and out of the estate. Is this not contrary to the expectations that we envisage in the renewal plan?

Column: 679



    Sir, we have to draw a lesson from this experience, i.e., a scheme or a policy may be very good in principle, but when it is executed, because the so-called experts in charge of the scheme are unaware of the local conditions and have not taken local factors into account, the actual result is far from ideal or as expected. It is not too late for us to take remedial action in respect of future schemes and in their execution. We must construct buildings which are in keeping with the requirements of the local people. In this respect, Sir, I am sure the Citizens' Consultative Committee in each constituency will be able to contribute their views to assist the experts.

    Another aspect about urban renewal is the sale of land and the identity of the investors. On this point, my former Parliamentary colleague, Mr Lee Teck Him, made some worthwhile contributions in last year's debate. According to present plans, we sell plots of land by open tenders and we provide the best opportunities and facilities for the rich developers to develop the land. But the small businessmen affected by clearance exercises in urban renewal do not get any concessions or preference. I feel this is most unwise. Many of the small and medium businessmen affected by urban renewal in fact are in a position to pool their resources and participate in urban renewal projects. I know of such a plan and of people not only in my own constituency but also in two other constituencies with such plans. No doubt, when they pool their resources, they are able to provide a sizable amount of local capital for development purposes. We should support such schemes to invest local capital in the development of our country and should also be of help to them. If we do so, we will not be accused of neglecting them and favouring the richer developers many of whom are foreign capitalists.

    Sir, a certain trade organisation has expressed its willingness to participate in such a development scheme. But a year or more has elapsed and there has been no answer from the Government to the proposal. If I compare the

Column: 680

treatment given to local people and that given to an American electronics company which has been given all the facilities required in the setting up of the industry within six weeks, I feel hurt and ashamed of the "efficiency" of the Government. There are two possible explanations for this. One explanation is that we are totally uninterested in the investment of local capital and will not give it any encouragement. The other explanation is that we are over-interested in foreign capital which is interested in us because we can provide it with cheap labour. We are afraid that if we do not welcome foreign investors enthusiastically, they will hesitate to come here. I do not think it is the intended policy of our intelligent and honourable Minister for Law and National Development. But I do not appreciate the doings of some experts in his Ministry.

    Sir, talking about experts brings me to another thought about the trend in our midst in recent years. Many people have faith in these experts as though they can provide them with all the panaceas in the world. I would remind those concerned that only those who are really aware of the basic requirements of life of our people are fit to propose plans for reform. Those scholars and experts who sit in air-conditioned rooms and talk about the hot weather and the plight of the hungry people outside must leave their air-conditioned rooms if they wish to understand our local conditions and get the views of the people at grass-root level before they can make any proposals or plans worthy of consideration.

    Sir, when I started speaking I mentioned the great effect of extraneous factors on us. I would like to come back to this subject. The Minister for Finance has also concurred on this point. He has particularly emphasised the potential influence of Japan as an industrial power on the economic development of this region. He shows very good understanding in this connection. But no word has been mentioned about another great power in Asia - I refer to the People's Republic of China. Of course, the People's Republic of China, with

Column: 681

her great land and human resources, will have to discharge her political and military obligations as a super power in the international arena. Sir, I have in this House requested the Government to reappraise and readjust the relations that we have with China, and I would like to urge the Government again to initiate positive and correct steps towards this end. There is no denying that China's joining the United Nations depends on whether she will get any benefit from such a move. Nobody can stop China from expanding her influence in South-east Asia. If our policy runs contrary to this inevitable trend, then it will be of no benefit to us. China may become a great market for the primary produce of this region. This will be of benefit to Singapore. Many people may feel that it would be unwise for us to be too friendly with China because the majority of the population here are of Chinese origin. I do not agree with this view. I was born and brought up in Singapore. If Singapore fails, I have no other place to turn to. So nobody can accuse me of speaking for Peking. I may not endorse the policies that are being implemented in that country. At the same time, I do not believe that China will come to the assistance of Singapore simply because it is largely populated with people of Chinese origin when we get into difficulties, unless China can benefit from such assistance given. My point is that after years of hard struggle, China will now assert her rights in the international arena and discharge her obligations as a great power and look after her own interests and strengthen her influence in this region. We cannot overlook this important foreign factor. We must take the initiative and make preparations for any future possible development.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, another extraneous political factor which deserves our attention is the co-operation we must have with our neighbouring countries. At the present stage, we hope to promote co-operation with our neighbours through regional mutual benefit schemes.

Column: 682

But have the principles and objectives of this co-operation been defined? Are they mutually acceptable to both? We must not forget that any political development in the peninsula to the north of us will definitely affect our small island state. Have we honestly sought for opportunities for co-operation with our neighbour on a mutually acceptable basis and tried to sink our differences while maintaining concord and come to some kind of co-operative arrangements which are mutually beneficial for our two peoples?

    Sir, we also cannot overlook the development of racial politics in the neighbouring countries which will have a certain reaction from us. As we believe in multi-racialism, our reaction to such development must be rational and be based on our accepted principles of multi-racialism. I hope our people, particularly the press, will avoid being dragged into expressing some kind of chauvinistic feelings. Certain of our local newspapers have a tendency to whip up chauvinistic feelings, perhaps unwittingly or for business reasons. I do not want to over-stress this point. It will be dangerous. Sir, I am not very optimistic about the development of our relationship with neighbouring countries. In fact, I can see that some dark clouds are already looming over the distant horizon.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, our Government is a socialist government. The interests of the workers must be protected. I welcome the Government's intention to strengthen the Factory Inspectorate in order to promote the safety of the workers. In fact, this should have been done long ago. The Chief Inspector of Factories has been able to work under the most unfavourable and strenuous conditions in the past and we should give him the commendation that is due.

    Talking about industrial safety brings me to another matter. When we relate the story of our industrialisation success, we must not forget to pay a tribute to the workers at the workshop level, because without their sacrifices and their efforts, we will not have attained

Column: 683

our present position. I have some rough statistics to prove that those who are standing in the forefront of industrialisation come mainly from those educated in their own mother tongue. This is a great tribute that we must pay to education in the mother tongue. Through education in the mother tongue, we have been able to bring up a generation of patriotic and hard-working industrial workers who are responsible for the happiness and well-being of our country. Their contribution to our country is too great to be denied. If anybody tries to deny this, it will be a great insult to our republic.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore is a young country. Our youths are a source of great strength. We must spare no effort to tap this source. However, history shows that any society of people who only care to enjoy life and nothing else will, in the end, become a soulless one and collapse. More than a decade ago the People's Action Party was able to provide our youth with the right objective in life - to contribute towards nation building. The situation today is quite different from that in the past. Our Government must not forget to guide our youths along the proper path to understand and cultivate the right attitude in life, and to inculcate in them the correct ideals about a new life and not ask them to be docile fancy fish. I feel it is most regrettable that the Government has mentioned nothing about this aspect. It must give active consideration to the problems of youths in Singapore.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the people in this region may be classified into two groups -- the forward-looking modernisers and the backward traditionalists. I believe that we today belong to the first category, and we want to be treated as such. We have to be prepared, within the shortest possible time, for the worst situation that may occur. Our economic policy must be geared along these lines. Our success depends on our ability to bring about a more just and more fair society for the majority of our people, and not work on statistics alone. Given

Column: 684

proper supervision and time to our present Government and with the established spirit of PAP leadership courageously wiping out all the opportunists in Singapore at all levels, there is no reason why we cannot succeed.

3.04 p.m.

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the Minister for Finance announced in the House on the 8th of this month that Singapore was not going to have any new taxes or increase in taxes in the coming financial year, all the people in Singapore received the news with great joy. Indeed, he brought tremendous news to the people of Singapore. This has stimulated a spirit of self-reliance and perseverance among the people of Singapore and has encouraged them to work even harder.

    Among the countries which have become independent after the Second World War, very few of them have been fortunate enough to be able to afford such a painless budget as ours. If we examine the reasons for our success, we will find that in the last 10 years or so, our Government has put up a creditable performance. It has established a clean and efficient government and has helped the people of Singapore in overcoming their difficulties, in creating a new environment, and in encouraging them to strive for a better future. On the other hand, the people of Singapore have worked very hard and have shown a spirit of endeavour and perseverance. This surely must go down in history as a great performance.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore has progressed from strength to strength for many years now. We have received news of one success after another. If we look at the newly emergent countries, we will find that many of them, especially in the Sixties, faced chaos and experienced great disappointment after their independence. Only the people of Singapore can "thumbs up" and say that in the last 10 years they have surmounted their difficulties. They are approaching an even brighter and glorious future. In

Column: 685

the last few years, they have had the benefit of painless budgets which have brought honour to our country. Despite this, many people have voiced their discontent. What is the reason for this? There must be a reason. As the Chinese saying goes, "There can be no wave without the wind." People in the lower income group, especially the wage-earners, have to draw up their household budget too. Of course, their budget is not comparable to the momentous one for the country drawn up by the Minister for Finance. The people, on the whole, are not concerned with development projects as such. They are not concerned so much with the increase of taxes or new tax rates because their household budget is based on the rise or fall of the general price level. A small number of unscrupulous merchants have recently raised the prices of many goods without good reasons. This has caused great hardships to the people. This is even worse than an increase in taxes. It is a most distressing thing to witness. What is worse is that these unscrupulous merchants have put the blame squarely on the Government.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, it is a fact that prices have increased tremendously in the last few years. The increase in the price level has been a general one, including prices for all the daily necessities: for example, tinned food, fish, vegetables, bread and so on. Even bus fares have gone up! There is indeed a general increase in the price level. Unscrupulous merchants have raised prices under the guise of price adjustments, but price adjustments are equivalent to price in-increases. We have never yet seen price adjustments leading to a downward revision of prices. It is only now that I understand price adjustments to be synonymous with price increases. It is a new term for price increases. Nowadays we often hear that this or that price must be adjusted, but we have not heard that the employers are going to adjust the wages of their workers. Let us take, for example, the salaries of teachers. The previous Minister for Education

Column: 686

promised the teachers salary adjustments, but nothing has happened although the relevant bodies submitted their recommendations six months ago. As the Chinese saying goes, "We can only hear the footsteps on the staircase, but we never see the people coming down." If we do not adjust the wages of the working class in the face of the general increase in the price level, this will lead to a fall in their income. It is for this reason that I would like to represent the people in my constituency and thank the Minister for Finance who has brought us this good news of a painless budget. I would also like to express the hope that a permanent price control committee will be set up to prevent unscrupulous merchants from raising prices without valid reasons.

3.15 p.m.

    Mr Sia Khoon Seong (Moulmein): Mr Speaker, Sir, no piece of information was more welcome to the people of Singapore than the declaration by the Minister for Finance in this House on the 8th March that no new taxation measures, either directly or indirectly, would be introduced in the ensuing financial year. The fact that the current needs for both ordinary and development expenditures can be met from the natural increase in the existing tax yields as a result of the rapid economic growth is eloquent testimony to the soundness and foresight of the economic planning and expansion programmes laid down by his predecessor.

    I note that the local newspapers have popularly termed the budget a painless one. That it would bring about "no harm" or "unhappiness" to the man in the street is an undeniable fact. Nonetheless, affluent employers have more cause to celebrate by reason of the tremendously "good cheer" the budget gave to them.

    Apart from the fact that no new taxes will be imposed on the excessively huge profits that the employers make, they are now to receive a new tax relief in that Government will use the proceeds of the existing payroll tax to defray their liability in respect of the

Column: 687

"make-up" pay of their employees doing national service, and to reimburse their expenses in operating approved training schemes or apprenticeship schemes for their employees. Such tax relief, according to the Finance Minister, is to lighten the so-called burden of the employers in these two areas.

    The questions that immediately strike my mind are (1) What is this so-called burden of the employers for which the Minister has such great solicitude? (2) Should the Government lighten this so-called burden of the employers with public funds that may be better utilised for some other more worthy purposes? I cannot emphasise too strongly that every tax relief is tantamount to a payment from the public funds, since the principal source of public funds is taxation in one form or other.

    The Finance Minister has proposed that employers are entitled to use public funds to pay part of their workers' wages for which they are liable under the National Service Act. It appears that workers are expected, as a matter of fact, to sacrifice two or three years of their youth in national service. But when it comes to the turn of employers to make a bit of sacrifice, it appears that they are a different breed entirely, and so are not governed by the same considerations of national interest as their less fortunate employees. It is of immaterial consequence to such employers that the whole and sole purpose of national service is not for the martial glory of Singapore but for its defence and protection as a sovereign political entity and the protection of the lives and property of the people of Singapore. I would have thought that employers stood to lose most if Singapore had no credible defence system to deter any would-be aggressor. But the mind of employers, obviously, functions in a different manner. They can perceive no contradiction in supporting national service when only employees are affected, and in agitating against the burden of make-up pay for their workers doing national service.

Column: 688



    I should think that no one in this House, least of all the representatives of employers, expects employers to take the lead in expressing and proving their patriotism. But their churlish reaction to the slight obligation they must incur, by way of contributions towards the defence of the country, comes as a definite surprise. The workers are making great personal sacrifices by shouldering the burden of national service. Apart from the sentiments of patriotism that cause them to respond with enthusiasm to the call of service to their country, they have no property or wealth of their own to defend. On the other hand, if something should happen to Singapore, employers have a lot to lose apart from their valuable lives. They apparently want to have their cake and eat it too. The petty attitude of employers is most ridiculous, considering that their so-called burden under the National Service Act is too insignificant to talk about. The amount of money that an employer has to give by way of the make-up pay is probably negligible in relation to his total profits or assets. Employers have no reason to grudge the payment of insurance premium in respect of their property. In fact, they consider it good and sound business practice to have such insurance cover. It is, therefore, extremely unreasonable for them to grudge the cost of national service which is, after all, the best and most comprehensive form of insurance that they can obtain for their property, their livelihood, or profit-making enterprises.

    I come now to the question of training schemes for the improvement of skills of workers and the offsetting of their training expenses against their payroll tax. I find it difficult to believe, by any stretch of imagination, that anyone has the gall to claim that any scheme to improve the skills of workers is more a burden than a benefit to their employers. All training schemes are designed for one primary objective - to improve the skills and efficiency of workers so that they may be able to contribute more effectively to the profit-making

Column: 689

capacity of their employers. Employers to enable their workers to acquire greater skills for their own good do not establish training schemes. Granted that it is true the Minister for Finance might have been induced to allow such tax relief by reason of the undertaking of a few foreign investors to train more workers than required under their own training schemes, but it will be most unfair for such employers, who are co-operating with the Government, to bear the brunt of training more workers than is necessary. This inducement to industrialists to train workers is not desirable as long as there is this problem of a vicious cycle of a consequent shortage of skilled workers resulting from the practice of poaching of such workers. The solution proposed by the Minister is not necessarily the most equitable one.

    The solution of allowing employers tax relief against their payroll tax liability for the purpose of increasing the supply of skilled workers is a negative approach since it entails the use of public funds. It must not be forgotten that while Singapore stands to benefit from a greater supply of skilled workers, the employers themselves benefit directly from it. In fact, they have the first call upon the services of the skilled workers in such increased supply. A positive approach would be to apportion the cost of training extra workers among all employers or those employers without any approved training schemes.

    Workers have done more than their share in Singapore's industrialisation programme. Seldom does a day pass by without a report of a worker being involved in an industrial accident, sometimes fatal. Whether he dies, or is permanently or temporarily incapacitated, he and his dependants can only expect miserable compensation under the Outdated Workmen's Compensation Ordinance. Even then, some employers try to wriggle out of their liability under it.

Column: 690
